discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
ANSWER IS D

Key Concept: TTL Manipulation
TTL (Time to Live) is a field in the IP header that determines how many hops a packet can take before being discarded. Each hop decreases the TTL by 1.

What Firewalk Does:
Firewalk sets the TTL to 1 (or another small value), so the packet expires at the first gateway (e.g., the Cisco PIX firewall in this case).

Why Traffic Doesn't Appear in the Sniffer Logs:
The sniffer is placed on a deeper subnet within the network.
Firewalk's packets with TTL set to 1 expire at the first firewall (gateway) and never make it past this point.
Since the packets don't reach the deeper subnet where the sniffer is located, they aren't logged or detected by the sniffer.

Selected Answer: D
D < ... It works by sending out TCP or UDP packets with a TTL one [hop greater than the targeted gateway].

The Firewalk tool typically sends packets with varying TTL values, starting with a TTL of 1 and incrementing it with each probe. By monitoring the responses to these packets, Firewalk can infer the behavior of the target firewall. If a packet with a specific TTL value is allowed to pass through the firewall and reach its intended destination, Firewalk deduces that the corresponding port is open. If the packet is blocked or dropped by the firewall, Firewalk determines that the port is closed.

--> Firewalk sets all packets with a TTL of one

Selected Answer: A
I think the best answer is A.
Firewalk is used to test the security of the firewall. If tested ports are closed or ICMP is droped by the firewall (which is a good security option) nothing will go trough the FW whatever the TTL. 
Another possibility is that the sniffer is placed too far from the target and the TTL is too low. So nothing reach the sniffer. 
But I prefere the A response.
Any other suggestion is welcomed

This is not correct. Firewalk does not set TTL of all packets to one... it sets the TTL to one hop greater than the target gateway.

The best answer is probably C, if this is the way the answers are actually worded on the exam question.

choices.A: Firewalk cannot pass through Cisco firewalls
choices.B: Firewalk sets all packets with a TTL of zero
choices.C: Firewalk cannot be detected by network sniffers
choices.D: Firewalk sets all packets with a TTL of one

questions.question_text: John is using Firewalk to test the security of his Cisco PIX firewall. He is also utilizing a sniffer located on a subnet that resides deep inside his network. After analyzing the sniffer log files, he does not see any of the traffic produced by Firewalk. Why is that?

choices.D: There are no ways of performing a "stealthy" wireless scan
choices.C: Nessus is not a network scanner

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer: A. Nessus is too loud

Explanations:

A. Nessus is too loud: Correct; Nessus generates high-traffic scans that are easily detected.
B. Nessus cannot perform wireless testing: Incorrect; Nessus supports wireless network testing.
C. Nessus is not a network scanner: Incorrect; Nessus is indeed a network vulnerability scanner.
D. There are no ways of performing a "stealthy" wireless scan: Incorrect; stealthy scans can be performed with tools designed for low visibility.

In this type of scan, also known as stealth scan, only a TCP frame is sent to a port. No additional TCP Handshaking process or additional Packet transfer information is sent in this type of scan and only a Single Frame is sent to the target to analyze the response given.

questions.question_text:
George is performing security analysis for Hammond and Sons LLC. He is testing security vulnerabilities of their wireless network. He plans on remaining as
"stealthy" as possible during the scan. Why would a scanner like Nessus is not recommended in this situation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. net port 22

The correct Ethereal (now known as Wireshark) filter is:
net port 22

Filter Components:

net
Purpose: Specifies the scope of the filter, focusing on network traffic.
Usage in Context: Captures packets related to the specified network or port, regardless of the direction (source or destination).


port
Purpose: Identifies packets based on a specific port number.
Usage in Context: Here, it isolates traffic associated with port 22, which is used by SSH and SFTP.


22
Purpose: Specifies the port number of interest.
Usage in Context: Captures all network packets communicating over port 22, used by SSH and SFTP.

Selected Answer: C
The answer seems to be C, SFTP (Secure File Transfer Protocol) uses net port 22, however, after revealing the correct answer, I was surprised. So, what is the difference between these two answers? For net port 22, the overall idea is that George is gonna look at all traffic through port 22, however, looking at src/dst 22 - this means that George is gonna look only at all traffic that comes from port 22 and goes only to port 22. Probably I did not understand the question correctly, but if the question states that George wants to see the communication of colleagues who has open port 22 and communication through this port - then the answer is okay, however, net port 22 also do the same and also covers other options that if his boss is communication with src = 22 and dst = other port -- Which is also possible

questions.question_text:
George is the network administrator of a large Internet company on the west coast. Per corporate policy, none of the employees in the company are allowed to use FTP or SFTP programs without obtaining approval from the IT department. Few managers are using SFTP program on their computers. Before talking to his boss, George wants to have some proof of their activity. George wants to use Ethereal to monitor network traffic, but only SFTP traffic to and from his network.
What filter should George use in Ethereal?
In Linux, what is the smallest possible shellcode?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
8 bytes

System Call Structure:
- Linux uses syscalls to interact with the kernel, and these are invoked using specific registers.
- The syscall for exit(0) (terminating the process) is one of the simplest examples.

8-Byte Example Shellcode (assembly code):
xor eax, eax ; Clears EAX register (sets exit code to 0)
inc eax ; Sets EAX to 1 (syscall number for `exit`)
xor ebx, ebx ; Clears EBX register (exit code argument)
int 0x80 ; Trigger the syscall interrupt

This shellcode:
- Sets up the syscall number for exit (1 in EAX).
- Clears the EBX register (sets exit code to 0).
- Executes the syscall with int 0x80.

Byte Representation (Machine Code):
The above assembly translates to an 8-byte machine code sequence: hexadecimal):

31 C0 40 31 DB CD 80

This is functional and minimal shellcode.

Here's a basic example of a small Linux shellcode in x86 assembly for spawning a shell:

assembly

section .text
global _start

_start:
 xor eax, eax ; Clear EAX register
 push eax ; Push a null byte onto the stack (terminating null)
 push 0x68732f2f ; Push "/bin/sh" onto the stack
 push 0x6e69622f
 mov ebx, esp ; Set EBX to point to the string "/bin/sh"
 push eax ; Push a null byte onto the stack (end of string)
 mov edx, esp ; Set EDX to point to the null byte
 push ebx ; Push the address of "/bin/sh" (EBX) onto the stack
 mov ecx, esp ; Set ECX to point to the address of "/bin/sh"
 mov al, 0xb ; Set AL to 11, which is the syscall number for execve
 int 0x80 ; Call the kernel to execute "/bin/sh"

This is a minimal shellcode that spawns a shell ("/bin/sh") and is only 23 bytes in size.

--> 24 bytes

I'm pretty sure the answer is actually 8, unless this question is outdated. You can find a number of examples of Linux shellcode on the internet that are smaller than 24 bytes. I've seen one as small as 10.
A: A false negative is when the scanner says there isn't a vulnerability, but there actually is.

questions.question_text:
Jim performed a vulnerability analysis on his network and found no potential problems. He runs another utility that executes exploits against his system to verify the results of the vulnerability test.
The second utility executes five known exploits against his network in which the vulnerability analysis said were not exploitable. What kind of results did Jim receive from his vulnerability analysis?
